comments:
(Does not happen under WinXP.)
Scenario is:
- run eclipse for build I20050617-0010 using the (to be) attached e31RC3 script;
- (note that the workspace can be empty - or not - this does not change the
  behavior);
- quit eclipse;
- replace eclipse with the RC3 build;
- relaunch the same script.
Effect is that an error is shown:

Interestingly enough, this has nothing to do with the presence of the
_gdk_x11_screen_get_window_manager_name function in so's (searched quite a while
around this), and the suppression of ~/.eclipse saves the situation (that is,
delete that directory and re-launch same script and you're fine).

Created an attachment (id=23643)
Exclipse launcher used to provoke the problem

Note that various attempts to start eclipse differently (many of them in fact)
were to no avail, whereas the described workaround seems reliable.

This happens because the two installs use the same location for the
configuration area
(<user.home>/.eclipse/org.eclipse.platform_3.1.0/configuration). Linux users are
expected to either delete the configuration directory manually or run at least
once with -clean when they switch to a new build during a release cycle. See bug
61139 comment 6 for a rationale.

*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 61139 ***

Thx a lot. And sorry for not finding the matching bugs myself (couldn't forge
the right query - got too many bugs or none on the five or so tries I made).

May I suggest that a comment be added on this topic somewhere in the
documentation, for example in the readme? The only reference I could find for
the -clean option is quite deeply nested into the Help system (Platform Plug-in
Developer Guide/Reference/Other reference information/Runtime options) and says
really nothing about the potential correlation of that option with weird
behaviors under Linux. I understand that this should not happen for a 3.0 -> 3.1
upgrade, but this could be of great help to Linux users who casually try
milestone releases.

If you consider changing the user documentation, please recommend more drastic
cleaning than -clean. To support this, the behavior I got today when upgrading
shows that -clean sometimes fail in circumstances where the removal of .eclipse
works.

Yes, the -clean is not taken into account by Update. So the config.ini file
created under your private configuration directory is pointing to the previously
used Eclipse shared configuration area.

I guess we could readme this (post 3.1) since the scenario happens often.

Original summary: "Keeping ~/.eclipse directory while upgrading from
I20050617-0010 to 3.1 RC3 crashes eclipse"
Marking for 3.2 RC3 to point people at the help pages on how to setup shared install from the readme.
Updating milestone for unfinished doc work
Oleg could you please take care of that and see with Kim to get it integrated properly.

I plan to add "-clean" in the list of Eclipse options (bug 100921). 

On another note, both content of the configuration directory and config.ini from 3.1 won't be compatible with 3.2. 

Pascal: I remember you added a comment on the usage of config.ini. Where did it go? Will it be sufficient or should we broaden it to the configuration directory as a whole?

The content of the configuration directory is not API and all the caches we have will be discarded and recreated since we versioned them. Therefore there is no need to doc this.

The note about the changes in the config.ini is located in incompatibilities.html.

For the 3.2 both format of the information stored in the configuration directory and config.ini has changed.

The upgrade seems to be working for me with the pair of Eclipse 3.1.2 and Eclipse 3.2 using the default configuration location. 

It won't work (due to the differences in the config.ini) in case the configuration directory is not in the default location.

The warning about config.ini was added into "Incompatibilities between Eclipse 3.1 and 3.2"; the description of the "-clean" will be added to the user options in the bug 100921.

Resolving as "wontfix" as while documentation portions of this are been addressed in other bugs, having stale caches still doesn't seem right. There is additional verification already build in (osgi.checkConfiguration=true) but it is turned off by default due to the extra stratup time required.
